front: How can a liquid conduct electricity?
back: An electrolyte can conduct electricity, as it has free moving ions in the solution that conduct charge.

front: What is Kirchoff's first law? Why is it a law?
back:
For any point in an electrical circuit, the sum of currents flowing into that point will equal the sum of currents flowing out of that point.
It is a law because of the fundamental physical property 'conservation of charge'.

• Get a container with electrolyte in it.
  • Positive electrode = anode
  • Negative electrode = cathode
  • Put electrodes in and create a potential difference with cell.
  • Cations go to cathode, anions go to anode, due to electrostatic attraction.
The average displacement per unit time of a charge carrier moving towards the positive terminal.

front: How do you measure the current in a circuit?
back: Use an ammeter in series at the point of lowest resistance.

front: What is the charge of a proton and electron in terms of e?
What experiment was used to determine the value of the elementary charge, and how?
back: Millikan's oil drop experiment was used to determine e. Oil was sprayed as small droplets between two oppositely charged plates. The voltage was adjusted until the droplets hovered mid-air. Now, the force of weight = force of electric attraction, and can be used to calculate e.

front: What is the definition of a Coulomb?
back: The flow of charge in a time of 1 second when thecurrent is 1 ampere.
The number of charge carriers per unit volume of a material.
The rate of flow of electrons.
The elementary charge is a quantised, fundamental unit of charge. It has a charge of 1.60e-19 coulombs.

front: How does the structure of a metal allow it to carry charge?
back:
• A metal is a regular crystal structure / lattice of positive ions in fixed positions.
  • The ions are surrounded by delocalised electrons which are free to move.
  • The electrons are able to carry charge.
